intro: Acer saccharum subsp. nigrum, commonly known as black sugar maple, is a subspecies of the sugar maple native to eastern North America. It is characterized by its dark green, palmately lobed leaves that turn vibrant shades of red and orange in the fall. The tree produces small, yellowish-green flowers in early spring, followed by winged seeds called samaras. It typically grows to heights of 20–30 meters and has a broad, spreading crown. This subspecies is valued for its ornamental appeal and is often planted in gardens and parks for its aesthetic foliage.
